## Meeting Overview

This document presents two main analyses:

1.  Good vs Bad Counties: Comparison of Fig 1 estimates using only good counties versus both good and bad counties, plus summary statistics.
2.  Figure 2 Specifications: Event study results across all six specifications showing quartile-specific estimates


------------------------------------------------------------------------

### Figure 1.1: Good Counties Only, Q4 {#fig-1-1}

![](images/12_12_25/good_county_4.png){#fig-1-1-plot}

### Summary Statistics: Good vs Bad Counties

```stata

Balanced Data
County x Year Observations
good_71     |      Freq.     Percent        Cum.
------------+-----------------------------------
          0 |      2,016        2.36        2.36
          1 |     83,384       97.64      100.00
------------+-----------------------------------
      Total |     85,400      100.00


Balanced Data
County 1971 Observations
good_71     |      Freq.     Percent        Cum.
------------+-----------------------------------
          0 |         36        2.36        2.36
          1 |      1,489       97.64      100.00
------------+-----------------------------------
      Total |      1,525      100.00

```

::: callout-note

If we just restrict based on 1971 alone the percent of bad counties is quite small (2.36%). For context, bad counties for 1970 and 1966 (the first year) make up **67.41%** and **67.71%** of observations respectively. 
:::

```stata
Balanced Data 1971
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

  1                   |            3.604887   2.531229               14186.34           1,025
  Total               |            3.612443   2.537705               14630.32           1,041
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

```

::: callout-note
The bad counties have slightly bigger expenditure and have a much larger population on average.
:::
